topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Donna introduces the core metaphor of discovering superpowers through discomfort, and Lenny sets up the episode’s focus on story-driven leadership, strengths, kryptonite, and personal growth.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for OneSchema and Sendbird.

topics.title: Donna’s origin story into executive coaching
topics.summary: Donna explains how a failed storytelling workshop with a conflicted executive team pushed her to spend a decade studying what actually makes leaders effective, leading her to coaching.

topics.title: Why personal stories shape leadership effectiveness
topics.summary: Donna reframes storytelling as primarily the internal narratives we live by; these stories (true or not) drive behavior, identity, and leadership impact.

topics.title: Inside-out leadership: start with yourself first
topics.summary: Donna argues leadership must begin with the leader’s inner purpose and self-leadership (concentric circles), because external validation is fragile and unsustainable.

topics.title: Case study: CEO rewrites limiting self-stories
topics.summary: Donna shares a CEO who believed he was “too nice” and not respected; by gathering real feedback from his team, they uncovered what people actually needed (vision, problems to solve, consistent presence).

topics.title: When the story is true: quiet leader example
topics.summary: A leader’s feedback (“too quiet”) was accurate, but the fix wasn’t forcing extroversion; it was clarifying her processing style and building a shared ‘personal OS/README’ for better collaboration.

topics.title: Imposter syndrome as a functional signal
topics.summary: Donna suggests reframing imposter syndrome by asking how it serves you; for one founder it triggered learning and growth, but needed boundaries to avoid overwork and burnout.

topics.title: Kryptonite: weaknesses that can be leveraged
topics.summary: Donna distinguishes avoidable kryptonite (e.g., scheduling) from inner kryptonite that can be reinterpreted as strength (e.g., dyslexia/ADHD, listening/quietness), emphasizing dosage and context.

topics.title: Superpowers: why strengths-based leadership works
topics.summary: They discuss how leaning into strengths can achieve the same outcomes via different styles (quiet vs charismatic leadership), including Lenny’s example of choosing writing over public speaking.

topics.title: How to identify your superpowers from stories
topics.summary: Donna recommends extracting strengths from peak experiences across childhood, recent work, and career path; she contrasts this with generic tests and shares a ‘connector’ example misread as “attention to detail.”

topics.title: Live coaching: Lenny’s peak experiences and themes
topics.summary: Donna guides Lenny through probing questions about starting/selling a startup to surface underlying drivers (proving capability, chip on shoulder), and they discuss how strengths can both help and hinder.
